(2) Abstract

Until now we have discussed the Web in terms of interactions between Web servers (where content is published) and Web browsers (where content is displayed). In actuality, things are a bit more complicated than that. There are many different kinds of Web intermediaries that may occupy the path between where content originates and where it is consumed. These intermediaries can provide a number of services, from improving performance to filtering content to protecting privacy.

(6) Intermediary Servers

  • The most common type of intermediary is called a proxy server
  • A proxy server is a separate computer between the client (computer on which the browser is running) and server
  • Proxy servers may be set up by the people operating a specific network (e.g) at a school or company)
  • Or they may be configured by an end user, in their browser settings or operating system settings


Intermediary Locations Gregory Jonason
University of Houston Jack J. Valenti School of Communication: Web Intermediaries

(7) Intermediaries in the Browser

  • Intermediaries are usually separate computers between the client and server
  • But we can also think of things like browser add-ons and extensions [Web Browsers; Add-Ons (1)] as intermediaries running in the browser
    • Firefox: Add-ons [https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/], user scripts [http://userscripts.org/], jetpacks [https://jetpack.mozillalabs.com/]
    • IE: Add-ons [http://www.ieaddons.com/], userscripts [http://iescripts.org/]
    • Chrome: Extensions [https://chrome.google.com/extensions]
    • Safari: Plugins [http://pimpmysafari.com/] (not to be confused with the other kind of plug-in [Web Browsers; Plug-Ins (1)])

(9) Modifying requests

  • Redirecting the request
  • Modifying request headers
  • Modifying form values
  • Adding/removing cookies


Intermediary Operations Gregory Jonason
University of Houston Jack J. Valenti School of Communication: Web Intermediaries

(10) Modifying responses

  • Inserting or removing content
  • Translating: formats, languages
  • Adapting or compressing
  • Adding annotations or overlays


Intermediary Operations Gregory Jonason
University of Houston Jack J. Valenti School of Communication: Web Intermediaries

(11) Passive monitoring

  • Logging statistics
  • Recording links followed
  • Storing copies of documents

Intermediary Applications Gregory Jonason
University of Houston Jack J. Valenti School of Communication: Web Intermediaries

(13) Improving Performance

  • Intermediaries are often used to improve performance (faster browsing) and save bandwidth
  • Rather than downloading content from a distant server, browsers can download from a server that is geographically close or connected by a fast (short) network link
  • This kind of intermediary is called a cache
  • Caches exist at different locations:
    • Caching in the browser
      • very close and fast, but only has copies of what a single user has downloaded
    • Caching in an organization's network
      • still close, and has copies of what everyone in the organization has downloaded--save the organization's bandwidth costs
    • Caching in a content distribution network
      • used by companies that want their content to be accessible quickly everywhere


Intermediary Applications Gregory Jonason
University of Houston Jack J. Valenti School of Communication: Web Intermediaries

(14) Content Distribution Network

Amazon CloudFront [http://aws.amazon.com/cloudfront/]



Intermediary Applications Gregory Jonason

(15) Content Modification

  • Intermediaries can be used to modify content
  • Removing ads is a popular use of intermediaries
  • NebuAd [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NebuAd] got in trouble for using intermediaries to insert ads
  • A more benign form of content modification is adaptation for mobile devices: CNN.com [http://cnn.com], CNN.com adapted for mobile [http://www.google.com/gwt/n?q=cnn.com&site=search&hl=en&lr=&c2coff=1&safe=off&mrestrict=xhtml&ct=res&cd=1&rd=1&u=www.cnn.com/]


Intermediary Applications Gregory Jonason
University of Houston Jack J. Valenti School of Communication: Web Intermediaries

(16) Protecting Privacy

  • An intermediary may be used to provide anonymity or protect privacy
    • Hide IP address of the client
    • Removing information from HTTP headers
    • Remove cookies or substitute fake ones
    • Generate fake "noise" activity to confuse monitoring
  • This can happen at different levels
    • In the browser, e.g. TrackMeNot [http://mrl.nyu.edu/~dhowe/trackmenot/]
    • In an organization's network, e.g. Tor [http://www.torproject.org/], GoogleSharing [http://www.googlesharing.net/]
    • On the Web: anonymous proxies (but be careful! [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anonymizer#Risks_and_security])


Intermediary Applications Gregory Jonason
University of Houston Jack J. Valenti School of Communication: Web Intermediaries

(17) GoogleSharing



Intermediary Applications Gregory Jonason

(18) Access Control

  • Intermediaries are often used for access control
  • Access control means both blocking and enabling access to resources
  • Our library uses a proxy [http://www.lib.berkeley.edu/Help/proxy.html] for enabling access to subscription resources for off-campus users
  • Schools and companies often use proxies for blocking access to porn, gambling, time-wasting sites
  • Control may occur at the URI level, or by actually examining the content of web pages
  • Whether it's used by companies [http://www.ironport.com/technology/ironport_web_usage_controls.html] or governments [http://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2008/03/-ldquo-the-connection-has-been-reset-rdquo/6650/], it's the same technology


Intermediary Applications Gregory Jonason
University of Houston Jack J. Valenti School of Communication: Web Intermediaries

(19) Monitoring & Surveillance

  • Even if they're not actively blocking content, most companies passively monitor employee's web usage
  • Be careful what you browse at work!
  • China's "Golden Shield" program relies as much on people's fear of being passively monitored as it does on actively blocking access
  • Monitoring can have positive uses as well
  • Statistics on usage of subscription resources can help organizations with planning
    • what isn't getting used?
    • who are the heaviest users?
    • should we be caching more?
